metadata.sermon_title: A Baptism about Which They Never Told Us
metadata.sermon_start_end: As you may know, Christmas stories occur only in the Gospels of Matthew and Luke, and we have now celebrated that. As you may know, the wise men occur only in the Gospel of Matthew, and that is why we celebrate Epiphany, when Jesus is revealed to the nations [...] Forgiveness and repentance are important, as John understood. Getting right with God is important; but there is more. Our faith is finally not about our being right with God. It is about being transformed by God’s power so that we may be open and vulnerable and courageous enough to be at God’s work of newness.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific passage. It treats Mark 1, Acts 19, and mentions Psalm 29 (though the latter is entirely ignored in the body). It functions as a thematic speech on 'baptism' rather than an exposition of a specific pericope. It misses what is unique to the Markan account by harmonizing it with general concepts of the Spirit.
quotes: So today, we think for twenty minutes about John the Baptizer, about the baptism of Jesus according to the Gospel of Mark, and about our own baptism.
In Acts 19, our second text for today, Paul is at Ephesus...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either Mark 1 or Acts 19. Identify what Mark 1:10-11 says that cannot be found in Matthew or Luke, and make that the sole starting point.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic understanding of the prophetic tradition and the historical context of John the Baptist. However, the exegesis remains at a surface level, focusing on 'poetic imagery' without deep engagement with the specific Greek nuances or the theological weight of the 'tearing' (schizomenous) of the heavens in Mark.
quotes: He is in fact an Old Testament figure, standing in continuity with the prophets of the Old Testament ... abrupt, demanding, urgent, sharp, threatening.
The voice of heaven quotes Psalm 2 with reference to David...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the study of the specific Markan vocabulary. Move beyond 'poetic imagery' to the theological necessity of the 'torn' heavens as a definitive act of God.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (consumerism, militarism, bourgeois church life). It attempts to bridge the text to the modern hearer's psychological state of 'control' versus 'vulnerability'. However, it leans toward a socio-political 'call to action' rather than a spiritual application of the Word itself.
quotes: We are so settled, so bourgeois, so rational, and so sure of ourselves— perhaps so liberal—that we would not want such an invasion of the spirit.
...commit acts of generosity and transformation and justice and reconciliation.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the specific text's uniqueness rather than a general critique of modern society.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured in blocks: first the narrative of Jesus, then the narrative of Ephesus, then the modern church. This 'lecturing' style keeps the hearer at a distance from the text until the final third. The 'present' of revelation is delayed.
quotes: I. In the story of Jesus’ baptism...
II. Since that day with Jesus, the church has been baptizing...
III. So consider: ... We may think about baptism in the church today.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the contemporary struggle with 'control' directly into the description of the heavens being torn open in Mark 1.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon explicitly mentions 'repentance' and 'forgiveness' (misery/redemption) but treats them as 'Old Testament' or 'preliminary' stages to be surpassed by 'empowerment'. This risks a shallow view of misery. Gratitude is framed as 'new deeds' rather than a response to the cross.
quotes: Forgiveness and repentance are important... but there is more. Our faith is finally not about our being right with God. It is about being transformed by God’s power...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Do not treat 'being right with God' as a secondary matter. Root the 'newness' more deeply in the redemption of the sinner, not just the empowerment of the activist.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon identifies a 'temporal loss' (society perishing due to greed/war). However, it lacks the 'eternal' dimension Dekker mentions. The choice is presented as becoming 'vulnerable' or staying 'settled', which lacks the gravity of the 'narrow way' leading to life versus destruction.
quotes: ...these are dangerous times in the world, when hate and war and greed and ambition are about to destroy us all...
...the church is so settled... that it tends to become irrelevant in our society.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the ultimate consequence of refusing the Spirit’s 'invasion'. Make the choice about the hearer's destination before God, not just societal relevance.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the subject, but he is portrayed primarily as an 'initiator' or 'agent' of a movement. The 'two natures' doctrine is not felt; Christ seems more like a model for our own 'vulnerability' than the Savior who is our life outside ourselves.
quotes: Jesus takes his place as the initiator of a whole new history of faithfulness to God in the world.
By the spirit we are made to be a new people that stirs things for good in the world.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Shift the focus from what we do 'like Jesus' to what Christ has done for us that we cannot do. Emphasize Christ as the 'telos' (God Himself) rather than a catalyst for human transformation.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1450 words, the sermon lasts about 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth'. The sermon remains too much on the surface of three different texts.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the length to at least 20 minutes by dwelling longer on the specific exegesis of one passage and its theological implications.

overall_assessment.summary: The text functions more as a thematic lecture on the theology of the Holy Spirit and social transformation than a sermon as defined by Dekker. It fails the formal requirement of focusing on one specific Bible passage, instead jumping between Mark and Acts. The exegesis is secondary to a pre-conceived narrative about 'vulnerability' and 'social justice'.
strengths: Clear identification of the 'zeitgeist' of control and bourgeois security.
Effective use of the concept of 'vulnerability' to translate the biblical 'spirit' into a psychological/sociological reality.
weaknesses: Lack of focus on a single pericope; the sermon is a 'speech about a keyword' (baptism/spirit).
Insufficient duration (under 20 minutes) leads to a lack of exegetical and dogmatic depth.
The 'two ways' are reduced to societal survival versus societal destruction, missing the individual's standing before God.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker’s definition. It is a thematic address that uses biblical passages as illustrations for a general theological idea. It lacks the specificity of 'this text' and the necessary breadth of time to reach true homiletical depth.
